original_data.question: A 6-week-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a post-natal visit. She was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 25-year-old woman via an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother reports that prenatal screening revealed no developmental abnormalities and that the baby has been gaining weight, feeding, stooling, and urinating appropriately. Physical exam of the infant is unremarkable. The mother has a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome and is curious about the development of her daughter's ovaries. Which of the following is true regarding the baby’s reproductive system at this time?

options.A: The baby has not yet developed oocytes
options.B: The baby’s oocytes are arrested in prophase
options.C: The baby’s oocytes are arrested in interphase
options.D: The baby’s oocytes are fully matured

model_response:
The baby’s oocytes are arrested in prophase.

The baby’s ovaries contain primordial follicles, but the oocytes within the primordial follicles are arrested in prophase. They will remain in this stage until puberty, when follicular development resumes. At this time, the oocytes enter meiosis and the first polar body is released. The first polar body can be seen with a light microscope. The first polar body may be released before birth, but the second polar body is not released until ovulation occurs, typically at puberty.

The baby has not yet developed oocytes.

The baby’s oocytes are not yet developed at this time. Oogenesis, the development of ova, begins in the fetus at 10 to 12 weeks gestation. At this time, the ovaries contain primordial follicles, but the oocytes within the primordial follicles are arrested in prophase. They will remain in this stage until puberty, when follicular development resumes.

The baby’s oocytes are arrested in interphase.

The baby’s oocytes are not yet developed at this time. Oogenesis, the development of ova, begins in the fetus at 10 to 12 weeks gestation. At this time, the ovaries contain primordial follicles, but the oocytes within the primordial follicles are arrested in prophase. They will remain in this stage until puberty, when follicular development resumes.

The baby’s oocytes are fully matured.

The baby’s oocytes are not yet developed at this time. Oogenesis, the development of ova, begins in the fetus at 10 to 12 weeks gestation. At this time, the ovaries contain primordial follicles, but the oocytes within the primordial follicles are arrested in prophase. They will remain in this stage until puberty, when follicular development resumes.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A medical doctor with specialized training in the care of children.
The event of being born.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Happening or arising without apparent external cause.
Female parents, human or animal.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
Performing various procedures and tests on the EMBRYO; FETUS; or mother for the detection of diseases.
Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
Increase in BODY WEIGHT over existing weight.
Excrement from the INTESTINES, containing unabsorbed solids, waste products, secretions, and BACTERIA of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
Female parents, human or animal.
Record and study of past events.

A complex disorder characterized by infertility, HIRSUTISM; OBESITY; and various menstrual disturbances such as OLIGOMENORRHEA; AMENORRHEA; ANOVULATION. Polycystic ovary syndrome is usually associated with bilateral enlarged ovaries studded with atretic follicles, not with cysts. The term, polycystic ovary, is misleading.
A female human offspring.

The reproductive organ (GONADS) in female animals. In vertebrates, the ovary contains two functional parts: the OVARIAN FOLLICLE for the production of female germ cells (OOGENESIS); and the endocrine cells (GRANULOSA CELLS; THECA CELLS; and LUTEAL CELLS) for the production of ESTROGENS and PROGESTERONE.
The external and internal organs involved in the functions of REPRODUCTION.
The dimension of the physical universe which, at a given place, orders the sequence of events. (McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms, 6th ed)
